questions.text: Which of the following is seen in osteoporosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Normal calcium and Normal ALP
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Normal calcium and Normal ALP Osteoporosis is associated with the normal calcium, phosphate and normal ALP levels. It is characterized by a diffuse reduction in bone density due to decrease in bone mass.

Highyeild:

Causes of Osteoporosis Glucocorticoid medications (ex cortisone, prednisone) Hypercalciuria (loss of calcium by urine) Hypogonadism (low testosterone levels) Anticonvulsant medications (ex. Dilantin) Excessive alcohol consumption Thyrotoxicosis (hyperthyroidism Smoking Hyperparathyroidism (increased parathyroid hormone levels) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma Neoplastic disease - cancer (ex. multiple myeloma) Gastrointestinal disease - malabsorption, prolonged use of PPI's Ankylosing spondylitis Rheumatoid arthritis Features Fractures occur on trivial trauma Commonly associated fractures – Colle’s fracture, hip fractures and vertebral fractures. Radiological findings Decreased vertical height of the vertebra Codfish vertebra Ground glass appearance Singh’s index, metacarpal index and vertebral index are some indices used to quantify osteoporosis Diagnosis T score of patient mineral density with that of young adult

Extraedge:

Treatment : Bisphosphonates Denosumab Parathyroid hormone Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) Strontium ranelate (Eg : Raloxifene) Cathepsin K inhibitor (odnacatib) Sclerostin inhibitor (Romosozumab)

#Mantra

questions.text: Match the following named fractures with their sites:Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a – 3, b – 1, c – 2, d – 4 Boxer’s fracture – It is the fracture of neck of 5 th metacarpal Jones fracture – Fracture at the metatarsal diaphyseal junction at the base of 5 th metatarsal Bennet’s fracture – Intra articular fracture of 1 st metacarpal March fracture – Stress fracture of shaft of 2 nd Usually occurs after prolonged march fast activity

questions.text: A patient has taken first dose of COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. The nurse noticed that his shoulder was flabby, flat and asymmetrical and loss of contour of the shoulder. Injury to which of the following structure during first dose of Vaccine may be responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deltoid The given clinical features are suggestive of axillary nerve injury which supplies deltoid muscle.

Highyeild:

Features of axillary nerve injury Weakness of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm Abduction from 15 – 90° is not possible Loss of contour of the shoulder Regimen badge sign (patch of sensory loss on lateral aspect of deltoid)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Rotator cuff- Diagnosis of rotator cuff tear is generally based on physical examination. Imaging tests which include X-ray, ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are recommended to rule out other conditions with similar symptoms. Option B. Posterior circumflex humeral artery The posterior humeral circumflex artery (posterior circumflex artery, posterior circumflex humeral artery) arises from the third part of axillary artery at the lower border of the subscapularis, and runs posteriorly with the axillary nerve through the quadrangular space. Option C. Deltoid The deltoid muscle is the muscle forming the rounded contour of the human shoulder. It is also known as the 'common shoulder muscle', particularly in other animals such as the domestic cat. Anatomically, the deltoid muscle appears to be made up of three distinct sets of muscle fibers.

Table:

#Mantra

questions.text: A 15 years old boy is brought to the emergency department after road traffic accident. He complained of pain over the hip region. The X ray image of the patient is given below. What is the next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Open reduction and reconstruction of posterior pillar of acetabulum

options.label: D
options.text: Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability

questions.correct_answer: D. Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability

Highyeild:

The given X ray image shows the posterior dislocation of left hip. The next step in the management of posterior dislocation of hip is closed reduction and assessment of hip stability Commonly occurs following dashboard injuries The position of the limb will be flexion, adduction and internal rotation X ray Upward dislocation of femoral head Lesser trochanter is not visualized Femoral head appears smaller than the normal The femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may be seen Treatment Closed reduction is done under sedation or GA Open reduction is done in cases of associated femoral neck fractures or failed closed reduction If there is delay in surgical correction, skeletal traction with a distal femoral traction pin can be done

Table:

#Mantra

questions.text: An elderly women came to the hospital as she slipped and fell at home and injured her hand. Colle’s fracture is diagnosed and POP cast is applied. What is the correct sequence of reduction of the fracture?

options.label: A
options.text: POP, traction, Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation

options.label: B
options.text: Traction, ulnar deviation, POP, Palmar flexion

options.label: C
options.text: Traction, Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP

options.label: D
options.text: Traction, ulnar deviation, Palmar flexion, POP

questions.correct_answer: C. Traction, Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Traction, Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP

Highyeild:

Colle’s fracture is the Extra articular fracture of distal end of radius with anterior or volar displacement of distal fragment. It is common in elderly due to osteoporosis It commonly occurs due to fall on outstretched hand Method of reduction Longitudinal traction – To disimpact the fracture fragments (counter traction is provided by the assistant) The distal fragment is then pressed into Palmar flexion followed by ulnar deviation The patient’s hand is drawn into pronation, Palmar flexion and ulnar deviation Colle’s cast is applied.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION A. Colle’s fracture is the Extra articular fracture of distal end of radius with anterior or volar displacement of distal fragment. OPTION:B. Longitudinal traction – To disimpact the fracture fragments (counter traction is provided by the assistant)

Table:

#Mantra

questions.text: Which of the following are true regarding open fractures? Compartment syndrome does not occur in open fractures Usually not associated with any other injuries Tibia and phalanges are more commonly involved Early debridement should be done Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.correct_answer: C. c and d are true
questions.explanation:
Solution:

c and d are true

Highyeild:

Antibiotic Dose Cefazolin (first-generation cephalosporin) 100 mg/kg/d divided into 3 doses every 8 h, maxi- mum 2 g per dose Gentamicin (aminoglycoside) 5-7.5 mg/kg/d divided into 3 doses every 8 h Penicillin 150,000 units/kg/d divided into 4 doses given every 6 h, maximum dose of 6 million units per dose Clindamycin 15-40 mg/kg/d divided into 3 doses every 8 h, maximum dose of 2.7 g/d

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Statement c 🡪 Most common sites involved in open fractures are pahalanges, tibial diaphysis, distal radius and ankle Statement d 🡪 Early debridement should be done in open fractures as these are more prone for infections Statement a 🡪 Compartment syndrome can occur in open fracture and the presence of open fracture does not prevent the development of compartment syndrome. Statement b 🡪 In open fractures, the fracture fragment is exposed to external environment. It is usually associated with multiple other injuries

Table:

#Mantra Open Fractures-Gustilo Classification 1,2 Type I Open fracture with a skin wound <1 cm in length and clean Type II Open fracture with a laceration >1 cm in length without extensive soft tissue damage, flaps, or avulsions. Type III Open segmental fracture with >10 cm wound with extensive soft tissue injury or a traumatic amputation (special categories in Type III include gunshot fractures and open fractures caused by farm injuries). IIIA Adequate soft tissue coverage. IIIa Significant soft tissue loss with exposed bone that requires soft tissue transfer to achieve coverage. IIIc Associated vascular injury that requires repair for limb preservation.

questions.text: Which of the following appears late in compartment syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paralysis Compartment syndrome occurs due to increased pressure in the muscle compartments in limbs.

Highyeild:

Cause of paralysis Due to increase in the content Bone – fractures (fractures of elbow, forearm, proximal third of tibia are at increased risk) Muscle – following crush injury Vessel – following vascular injury Due to decreased size/volume of the compartment Tight cast Features – 5 P's Pain – first symptom, pain occurs on passive stretching of the muscles Paresthesia – Due to the compassion of nerves traversing the affected compartment Pallor Paralysis – late sign Pulselessness – usually pulses are intact in the early stages unless there is a major arterial injury. Differential pressure – The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as differential pressure. If differential pressure is less than 30mmHg, immediate compartment decompression is indicated Treatment Fasciotomy

questions.text: A male patient present with inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joints of 4th and 5th digits. He was not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. Identify the site of injury:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

D

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - The given clinical features of inability to flex 4 th and 5 th interphalangeal joints and positive card test suggest ulnar nerve injury The most likely site of injury leading to ulnar nerve injury is medial epicondyle, marked as D in the given image. Site marked M/C nerve injured A Surgical neck of humerus Axillary nerve B Radial groove Radial nerve C Lateral condyle of humerus Tardy ulnar nerve palsy D Medial condyle of humerus Ulnar nerve
